actions: Medication Management (Dose modification, New prescription added, Delivery/Confirmation)
Diagnostics & Tests (Lab tests ordered: BNP, electrolytes; Imaging: Ultrasound/X-ray)
Monitoring Adjustments (Intensified observation, Remote vitals review)

Lab test sampling at patient home
Results uploaded automatically for doctor review

diagnosisMetadata.title: AI Differential Diagnosis
diagnosisMetadata.subtitle: Based on vital trends & historical data

diagnosis.name: Acute exacerbation of unspecified chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Pulmonary embolism without acute cor pulmonale

diagnosisDetails.name: Acute exacerbation of unspecified chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
diagnosisDetails.description: Patient has a history of COPD and presents with acute, progressive worsening of respiratory rate, heart rate, and oxygen saturation. This is a common and severe complication of COPD.

diagnosisDetails.name: Pneumonia, unspecified organism
diagnosisDetails.description: Pneumonia is a common trigger for COPD exacerbations and can lead to rapid respiratory deterioration in elderly patients, especially those with underlying chronic lung disease. The acute worsening of vitals is consistent with an infectious process.

diagnosisDetails.name: Acute heart failure, unspecified
diagnosisDetails.description: Given the patient's age and history of hypertension and diabetes, acute heart failure could manifest with acute respiratory distress, increasing heart rate, and hypoxemia, mimicking a primary respiratory event.

diagnosisDetails.name: Pulmonary embolism without acute cor pulmonale
diagnosisDetails.description: While less likely without specific risk factors like recent surgery or immobility, pulmonary embolism is a critical cause of acute dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypoxemia that must be considered in any acute respiratory deterioration, especially in an elderly patient.

timeline.event: AI initiated call to patient (Symptom Check)
AI Assessment: Early Heart Failure Exacerbation

actions: Medication Management (Increase Diuretics: Lasix 40mg -> 80mg, Add Potassium: K-Dur 20mEq)
Diagnostics & Tests (STAT Electrolytes, BNP, Scheduled within 24 hours)
Monitoring Adjustments (Daily Weight Monitoring, Twice Daily BP Checks, Telehealth follow-up in 48 hours)
labDispatch: Result Notification to MD & Case Manager

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Good morning, this is your personal Monitoring agent calling from the Remote Monitoring Team at CHI. Am I speaking with Mr. Johnson?

Hi Mr. Johnson! I'm reaching out because we've been monitoring your vitals remotely over the past few days... I see that your heart rate has been gradually increasing... and your blood pressure has also been trending upward... and your weight has gone up about two and a half pounds.
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: Hmm, I didn't realize it had gone up that much.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Have you been experiencing any shortness of breath lately?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: A little bit, yeah. Mostly when I'm walking around or doing things - you know, on exertion. But not when I'm just sitting.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: And what about your legs - have you noticed any increased swelling, particularly in your ankles or feet?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: Actually, yes! My ankles have been looking puffier the last couple of days. I thought maybe I was just on my feet too much.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Have you had any recent infections or been running a fever? ... Have you been taking all your medications as prescribed?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: No fever... Yes, absolutely. I take them every day.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Let me ask you about your diet - have there been any recent changes? Maybe eaten out more than usual, or had any particularly salty foods?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: Oh! Well, actually... yeah. I went to a family gathering over the weekend and had some pretty salty food - you know, chips, deli meats, that sort of thing. Could that be it?

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: One more question - how has your sleep been? Any trouble breathing when you're lying flat?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: I've actually been sleeping propped up on a couple of pillows the last few nights. I just feel more comfortable that way.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Based on what you're telling me... it looks like you might be experiencing some early fluid overload... I'm going to bring in Nurse Sarah. She's been listening to our call.
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: Oh... is this serious? ... Yes, thank you for calling.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Nurse Sarah: Hello Mr. Johnson... I'm going to send a message to Dr. Patel about possibly adjusting your diuretic medication temporarily.

diagnosisMetadata.title: Differential Diagnosis - Updated Probabilities
diagnosisMetadata.subtitle: AI Analysis: Based on vital data + patient responses

diagnosis.name: Acute on chronic systolic (congestive) heart failure
Acute on chronic diastolic (congestive) heart failure

diagnosisDetails.name: Acute on chronic systolic (congestive) heart failure
diagnosisDetails.description: Patient presents with classic signs and symptoms of acute heart failure decompensation on a likely chronic background, including increased heart rate and blood pressure, significant weight gain, mild shortness of breath on exertion, increased bilateral ankle swelling, and orthopnea, further exacerbated by recent high salt intake.

diagnosisDetails.name: Acute on chronic diastolic (congestive) heart failure
diagnosisDetails.description: Similar to systolic heart failure, diastolic dysfunction can lead to acute fluid overload with the presented symptoms. Differentiating between systolic and diastolic often requires further cardiac evaluation.

diagnosisDetails.name: Fluid overload, unspecified
diagnosisDetails.description: This diagnosis directly aligns with the nurse's assessment of 'early fluid overload' and the patient's symptoms of weight gain and ankle swelling, along with recent high salt intake.

diagnosisDetails.name: Acute kidney failure, unspecified
diagnosisDetails.description: Acute kidney injury can lead to fluid retention, weight gain, and elevated blood pressure and heart rate. While there are no specific renal symptoms, it remains a differential given the fluid overload presentation.

diagnosisDetails.name: Unspecified pulmonary edema
diagnosisDetails.description: Pulmonary edema is a common manifestation of fluid overload and heart failure, causing shortness of breath and orthopnea. The patient's reported mild SOB and need to sleep propped up are consistent with this, though a chest X-ray would be needed for confirmation.

initialDiagnosis.name: Acute exacerbation chronic congestive heart failure

treatmentDetails.title: Evidence-Based Treatment for Acute Heart Failure Exacerbation

timeline.event: Patient initiated AI symptom Check Assessment

diagnosisMetadata.title: Differential Diagnosis - Updated Probabilities
diagnosisMetadata.subtitle: AI Analysis: Critical Neurological Flags Detected

diagnosisDetails.name: Bacterial meningitis, unspecified
diagnosisDetails.description: Patient presents with high fever (102.3F), severe headache (8/10, behind eyes, base of skull), significant neck stiffness, positive nuchal rigidity (pain with chin to chest), photophobia, and vomiting. These are classic signs of bacterial meningitis, which is a medical emergency requiring immediate investigation and treatment.

diagnosisDetails.name: Viral meningitis, unspecified
diagnosisDetails.description: Many symptoms overlap with bacterial meningitis, including fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, and vomiting. Viral meningitis is generally less severe but still requires urgent medical evaluation and differentiation from bacterial causes.

diagnosisDetails.name: Encephalitis, myelitis and encephalomyelitis, unspecified
diagnosisDetails.description: Though the patient denies confusion, encephalitis remains a critical differential in the context of high fever, severe headache, and meningeal signs. It involves inflammation of the brain itself and can present with similar symptoms.

diagnosisDetails.name: Influenza, unspecified
diagnosisDetails.description: Patient has fever and headache, and a coworker had the flu. However, the prominent nuchal rigidity and photophobia are typical for uncomplicated influenza and suggest a more serious central nervous system process.

diagnosisDetails.name: Acute sinusitis, unspecified
diagnosisDetails.description: Sinusitis can cause headache (especially behind eyes) and fever. However, the severity of headache (8/10), prominent nuchal rigidity, photophobia, and vomiting are not typical for isolated sinusitis.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Welcome to the Virtual Health Symptom Checker. What brings you here today?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: I've been feeling really sick. I have a fever and my head is killing me.
The headache started yesterday morning, but the fever came on last night.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate your current headache?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: I'd say it's about an 8. It's really bad, especially behind my eyes and at the base of my skull.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Have you noticed any stiffness in your neck or difficulty moving your head?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: Yes, actually. My neck feels really stiff.
symptomCheckerTranscript.alert: Initial Red Flag: Nuchal Rigidity Reported

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Can you try to tuck your chin in and touch your chest with it?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: No, it hurts to look down or touch my chin to my chest.
symptomCheckerTranscript.alertDesc: Inability to flex neck suggests meningitis.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Have you experienced: Confusion? Sensitivity to light? Nausea/Vomiting? Rash?
symptomCheckerTranscript.patient: Yes to light sensitivity - bright lights bother me. Vomited once this morning. No rash.
I checked about an hour ago and it was 102.3°F.
No travel. Coworker had flu last week.

symptomCheckerTranscript.system: Do you have any chronic medical conditions?
